timeline.bodyText: Unfortunately had to modify createLayers() and computeEntrypoint() to no longer accept parameters for the sake of consistency. In the case of createLayers(), while explode mode requires a temporary directory, packaged mode doesn't. On the other hand, computeEntrypoint() for spring-boot exploded doesn't require the jarPath but the same for spring-boot packaged does. The jarPath and temporaryDirectory now need to be set with the help of setters.
timeline.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText: I like the idea of moving all the logic out of Jar. I'm just not sure about having it in JarModeProcessorHelper since it is supposed to contain only redundant code for the JarModeProcessor? That being said, it was probably a mistake to have it contain determineJarType at all. How does creating a separate class for this sound?
replies.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText:
Yeah sure.
These are just my ideas, but I think something along these lines could work?
JarProcessors -> has static method for JarProcessor creation from
Remove Mode from most names since we're not exposing that anymore
JarModeProcessor -- rename --> JarProcessor
StandardPackagedModeProcessor -> StandardPackagedJarProcessor... etc?
JarProcessorHelper is kind of a strange name because it doesn't truly say what it is doing (which is the trap that we often fall into when writing helpers), perhaps it could be called JarLayers or something?
replies.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText:
Yes that's a good idea. JarProcessors may sometimes be mistaken for JarProcessor. I'm still struggling to find a fitting name but what do you think of JarProcessorSelector?

JarProcessorHelper is kind of a strange name because it doesn't truly say what it is doing (which is the trap that we often fall into when writing helpers), perhaps it could be called JarLayers or something?

JarLayers is an accurate name, thank you! It describes the intent of the class pretty well.
replies.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText: The name JarProcessors is a pretty common pattern in java, Path and Paths for example, and we also use it all over the place in Jib. I'm not too concerned with any confusion there.
